awd_titl_txt: P2C2: Dry or Wet in East Asia During Heinrich Events? New Perspectives from Multiproxy Cave Records and Coupled Model Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to disentangle large-scale Asian monsoon circulation from local hydroclimate variability during North Atlantic cooling events of the last glacial cycle (i.e., Heinrich events) using a suite of speleothems from the middle reaches of the Yangtze River in central-eastern China.  

The project provides support for a postdoctoral research fellow and extensive undergraduate research experience for students at William Paterson University as a primarily undergraduate teaching university with a diverse student body (Hispanic Serving Institution designated by USDOE), including many first generation to attend college.

Coupled General Circulation Model (CGCM) simulations suggest that East Asia is likely to get wetter with climatic warming, yet there is still much uncertainty in these projections due in large part to the lack of agreement among model simulations.  Reducing these model biases is one of the more pertinent and challenging aspects of modern climate science as a means to provide strategies to meet the future needs in food, water, energy, and biological diversity.

Currently, there is a lack a consistent understanding of precisely how sensitive local rainfall variability in central China is to regional perturbations in the Asian monsoon because knowledge of the monsoon in central East Asia principally relies upon oxygen-isotope records which, according to new research, may not necessarily reflect local hydroclimate.  Therefore, this project aims to build a more complete picture of local rainfall variability in central-eastern China by addressing the following questions: (1) Can speleothem proxies, such as trace elements (Magnesium, Strontium, Barium) be used to deconvolve regional atmospheric circulation from local hydrology in East Asia. If so, (2) what do these alterative proxies inform us about local hydroclimate in central-eastern China and what are the mechanisms to explain the proxy-inferred changes. (3) How well do the proxy reconstructions match the paleo-simulations from coupled general circulation models (CGCMs). 

The main objectives of the project include: (1) reconstruct local hydrology in central-eastern China during Heinrich events 1-6 utilizing speleothem trace elements and isotope ratios from a suite of well-dated speleothems from four caves located in the middle reaches of the Yangtze River; (2) delineate the mechanisms for the hydrologic patterns observed in the proxies using the Community Earth System Model CGCM simulations; and (3) conduct model-proxy syntheses in space and time by directly comparing speleothem pseudoproxy time series--constructed using climate model output coupled with Proxy System Models (PSMs)--with measured isotope profiles.

To address the above objectives the researchers aim to test the following hypotheses: (1) Despite a weakened Indian monsoon, central China was wetter during Heinrich events thereby challenging the longstanding paradigm that the East Asian Monsoon (EASM) became weaker during North Atlantic (NA) cooling; (2) The higher rainfall in central-eastern China can best be explained by a seasonally-lagged onset of the mei-yu stage of monsoon evolution. A later onset of mei-yu to midsummer during NA cooling would have resulted in a shorter midsummer stage, leaving south-central China wet at the expense of dry conditions to the north; (3) Vegetation demise and subsequent higher dust emissions from the Sahara/Sahel regions during Heinrich events, affected the position of the ITCZ and thus amplified the response outlined in hypothesis (2); (4) Comparison of speleothem pseudoproxy time series (generated from PSMs) with measured records from East Asia will help to identify the dominant controls on speleothem delta 18-Oxygen.  It may also allow a more robust assessment of model skill and help to better evaluate any model-proxy biases through abrupt climate change events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
General Circulation Models (GCMs) project that East Asia is likely to overall get wetter as the planet continues to warm, yet there is still much uncertainty in these projections due to the lack of agreement amongst the CMIP model simulations as reported in the most recent IPCC report. Reducing these model biases is arguably one of the most pertinent, and challenging, aspects of modern climate science, as policymakers seek to provide sustainable development strategies to the region that will meet the future needs in food, water, energy, and biological diversity. Of particular importance is elucidating the spatial and temporal variability in climate extremes, such as droughts/floods and/or shifts in the timing and distribution of annual rainfall, which can have adverse societal and economic impacts on the region, and lead to widespread famine to indigenous communities that rely on the freshwater ecosystems. Gaining a deeper understanding as to how past rainfall variability in the region responded to changing boundary conditions (e.g. melting of large ice sheets in the higher latitudes, changes in atmospheric CO2) is thus of great importance in  helping us to not only improve the calibration of GCM simulations, but also provide critical bench marks for what is possible in terms of the rates and magnitudes of hydroclimate change in a region that occupies half of the world’s population. Achieving such a feat, however, has been met with some challenges because our current understanding of East Asian monsoon variability in the past, such as during abrupt climate events of the last deglaciation, has primarily relied on the oxygen isotope (18O/16O or d18O) records of speleothems, which, according to new research, are not necessarily a good indicator of local water balance. 

 

This project sought to disentangle large-scale Asian monsoon circulation from local hydroclimate variability during North Atlantic climate anomalies of previous glacial-interglacial cycles using a host of speleothem records from the middle reaches of the Yangtze River Valley. Specifically, our goals were to build a more nuanced picture of both monsoon circulation and hydroclimate variability in central-eastern China. To do so, we produced multiproxy records from a large suite of speleothems from central-eastern China covering Termination II (T-II) and Marine Isotope Stages (MIS) 6 and 11. We examined the speleothem growth frequency, δ18O and δ13C, and trace elements to help deconvolve large-scale EASM circulation (inferred from δ18O) from local hydroclimate (inferred from speleothem growth frequency, δ13C, and trace elements) on orbital scales. Results show an orbital-scale ‘dipole’ in hydroclimate across monsoonal eastern China, with wetter conditions in the south and drier conditions in the north when summer insolation was low and the monsoon was weak. Based on climate model simulations, we hypothesize that the orbital-scale westerly jet transition affects the East Asian summer rainband position and thus the orbital hydroclimate pattern in eastern China, while the low latitude transport of moisture from the Indo-Pacific amplifies the hydroclimate contrast during glacial-interglacial transitions. These results are important for two main reasons: (1) they challenge the longstanding paradigm that East Asia was overall wetter during insolation maxima, instead suggesting a more heterogenous hydroclimate response to changes in orbital forcing; and (2) persistent megadroughts in central-eastern China during Northern Hemisphere warming events may illuminate future impacts in the region. Indeed, observations show a significant decrease in soil moisture in recent decades across the region, consistent with the geologic record. 

 

A persistent source of uncertainty in climate model skill in both past, present, and future simulations is related to cloud and convective processes, which occur at scales too small to be explicitly resolved, and thus require parameterizations to be represented in climate models. In this project, we also designed a novel framework for constraining these parameter sets in a climate model using both present day observations of cloud properties and paleoclimate proxy data. Specifically, using multiple satellite climatologies and a global database of speleothem δ18O records, we demonstrated the potential of paleoclimates to constrain cloud and convective parameterizations in a perturbed parameter ensemble of the atmosphere-only version of the NASA GISS Model E2.1. Relative to the modern interannual variability, mid-Holocene (MH) and Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) simulations show greater sensitivity to parameter changes, allowing for an evaluation of model uncertainties over a broader range of climate forcing and the identification of parts of the world that are parameter sensitive, serving as likely targets to develop new archives or records. Certain simulations reproduced absolute δ18O values across all time periods, along with LGM and MH δ18O anomalies relative to PI, better than the default parameterization. Yet, no single set of parameterizations worked well in all climate states, likely due to the non-stationarity of cloud feedbacks under varying boundary conditions. This time period-dependent skill thus motivates the need to simultaneously perturb multiple parameter sets with coupled ocean feedbacks to determine optimal parameter sets across key time periods.
